verses.text: From the beauty of the color, say they, and the sweetness of the taste; this is evident; and as these are not found in rotten substances, we learn that their good has been taken from them.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:9
verses.text: Are they not ashamed to attribute the finding of God to the nose and the palate? But I pass from this.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:10
verses.text: For I will speak, using words in their proper sense; and, as the saying is, this is not so easy in speaking to you.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:11
verses.text: Let us see rather what sort of mind is required to understand this; how, if the presence of good in bodies is shown by their color, the dung of animals, the refuse of flesh itself, has all kinds of bright colors, sometimes white, often golden; and so on, though these are what you take in fruits and flowers as proofs of the presence and indwelling of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:12
verses.text: Why is it that in a rose you hold the red color to be an indication of an abundance of good, while the same color in blood you condemn? Why do you regard with pleasure in a violet the same color which you turn away from in cases of cholera, or of people with jaundice, or in the excrement of infants? Why do you believe the light, shining appearance of oil to be a sign of a plentiful admixture of good, which you readily set about purifying by taking the oil into your throats and stomachs, while you are afraid to touch your lips with a drop of fat, though it has the same shining appearance as oil? Why do you look upon a yellow melon as part of the treasures of God, and not rancid bacon fat or the yolk of an egg? Why do you think that whiteness in a lettuce proclaims God, and not in milk? So much for colors, as regards which (to mention nothing else) you cannot compare any flower-clad meadow with the wings and feathers of a single peacock, though these are of flesh and of fleshly origin.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:13
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:14
verses.text: Again, if this good is discovered also by smell, perfumes of excellent smell are made from the flesh of some animals.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:15
verses.text: And the smell of food, when cooked along with flesh of delicate flavor, is better than if cooked without it.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:16
verses.text: Once more, if you think that the things that have a better smell than others are therefore cleaner, there is a kind of mud which you ought to take to your meals instead of water from the cistern; for dry earth moistened with rain has an odor most agreeable to the sense, and this sort of mud has a better smell than rain-water taken by itself.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:17
verses.text: But if we must have the authority of taste to prove the presence in any object of part of God, he must dwell in dates and honey more than in pork, but more in pork than in beans.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:18
verses.text: I grant that He dwells more in a fig than in a liver; but then you must allow that He is more in liver than in beet.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:19
verses.text: And, on this principle, must you not confess that some plants, which none of you can doubt to be cleaner than flesh, receive God from this very flesh, if we are to think of God as mixed with the flavor? For both cabbages taste better when cooked along with flesh; and, while we cannot relish the plants on which cattle feed, when these are turned into milk we think them improved in color, and find them very agreeable to the taste.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:20
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:21
verses.text: Or must we think that good is to be found in greater quantity where the three good qualities—a good color, and smell, and taste—are found together? Then you must not admire and praise flowers so much, as you cannot admit them to be tried at the tribunal of the palate.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:22
verses.text: At least you must not prefer purslain to flesh, since flesh when cooked is superior in color, smell, and taste.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:23
verses.text: A young pig roasted (for your ideas on this subject force us to discuss good and evil with you as if you were cooks and confectioners, instead of men of reading or literary taste) is bright in color, and agreeable in smell, and pleasant in taste.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:24
verses.text: Here is a perfect evidence of the presence of the divine substance.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:25
verses.text: You are invited by this threefold testimony, and called on to purify this substance by your sanctity.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:26
verses.text: Make the attack.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:27
verses.text: Why do you hold back? What objection have you to make.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:28
verses.text: In color alone the excrement of an infant surpasses lentils; in smell alone a roast morsel surpasses a soft green fig; in taste alone a kid when slaughtered surpasses the plant which it fed on when alive: and we have found a kind of flesh in flavor of which all three give evidence.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:29
verses.text: What more do you require? What reply will you make? Why should eating meat make you unclean, if using such monstrosities in discussion does not? And, above all, the rays of the sun, which you surely think more of than all animal or vegetable food, have no smell or taste, and are remarkable among other substances only by their eminently bright color; which is a loud call to you, and an obligation, in spite of yourselves, to place nothing higher than a bright color among the evidences of an admixture of good.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:30
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:31
verses.text: Thus you are forced into this difficulty, that you must acknowledge the part of God as dwelling more in blood, and in the filthy but bright-colored animal refuse which is thrown out in the streets, than in the pale leaves of the olive.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:32
verses.text: If you reply, as you actually do, that olive leaves when burnt give out a flame, which proves the presence of light, while flesh when burnt does not, what will you say of oil, which lights nearly all the lamps in Italy? What of cow dung (which surely is more unclean than the flesh), which peasants use when dry as fuel, so that the fire is always at hand, and the liberation of the smoke is always going on? And if brightness and lustre prove a greater presence of the divine part, why do you yourselves not purify it, why not appropriate it, why not liberate it? For it is found chiefly in flowers, not to speak of blood and countless things almost the same as blood in flesh or coming from it, and yet you cannot feed on flowers.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:33
verses.text: And even if you were to eat flesh, you would certainly not take with your gruel the scales of fish, or some worms and flies, though these all shine with a light of their own in the dark.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:34
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:35
verses.text: What then remains, but that you should cease saying that you have in your eyes, nose, and palate sufficient means of testing the presence of the divine part in material objects? And, without these means, how can you tell not only that there is a greater part of God in plants than in flesh, but that there is any part in plants at all? Are you led to think this by their beauty—not the beauty of agreeable color, but that of agreement of parts? An excellent reason, in my opinion.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:36
verses.text: For you will never be so bold as to compare twisted pieces of wood with the bodies of animals, which are formed of members answering to one another.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:37
verses.text: But if you choose the testimony of the senses, as those must do who cannot see with their mind the full force of existence, how do you prove that the substance of good escapes from bodies in course of time, and by some kind of attrition, but because God has gone out of it, according to your view, and has left one place for another? The whole is absurd.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:38
verses.text: But, as far as I can judge, there are no marks or appearances to give rise to this opinion.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:39
verses.text: For many things plucked from trees, or pulled out of the ground, are the better of some interval of time before we use them for food, as leeks and endive, lettuce, grapes, apples, figs, and some pears; and there are many other things which get a better color when they are not used immediately after being plucked, besides being more wholesome for the body, and having a finer flavor to the palate.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:40
verses.text: But these things should not possess all these excellent and agreeable qualities, if, as you say, they become more destitute of good the longer they are kept after separation from their mother earth.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:41
verses.text: Animal food itself is better and more fit for use the day after the animal is killed; but this should not be, if, as you hold, it possessed more good immediately after the slaughter than next day, when more of the divine substance had escaped.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:42
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:43
verses.text: Who does not know that wine becomes purer and better by age? Nor is it, as you think, more tempting to the destruction of the senses, but more useful for invigorating the body,—only let there be moderation, which ought to control everything.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:44
verses.text: The senses are sooner destroyed by new wine.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:45
verses.text: When the must has been only a short time in the vat, and has begun to ferment, it makes those who look down into it fall headlong, affecting their brain, so that without assistance they would perish.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:46
verses.text: And as regards health, every one knows that bodies are swollen up and injuriously distended by new wine? Has it these bad properties because there is more good in it? Are they not found in wine when old because a good deal of the divine substance has gone? An absurd thing to say, especially for you, who prove the divine presence by the pleasing effect produced on your eyes, nose, and palate! And what a contradiction it is to make wine the poison of the princes of darkness, and yet to eat grapes! Has it more of the poison when in the cup than when in the cluster? Or if the evil remains unmixed after the good is gone, and that by the process of time, how is it that the same grapes, when hung up for awhile, become milder, sweeter, and more wholesome? or how does the wine itself, as already mentioned, become purer and brighter when the light has gone, and more wholesome by the loss of the beneficial substance?  45.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:47
verses.text: What are we to say of wood and leaves, which in course of time become dry, but cannot be the worse on that account in your estimation? For while they lose that which produces smoke, they retain that from which a bright flame arises; and, to judge by the clearness, which you think so much of, there is more good in the dry than in the green.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:48
verses.text: Hence you must either deny that there is more of God in the pure light than in the smoky one, which will upset all your evidences; or you must allow it to be possible that, when plants are plucked up, or branches plucked off, and kept for a time, more of the nature of evil may escape from them than of the nature of good.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:49
verses.text: And, on the strength of this, we shall hold that more evil may go off from plucked fruits; and so more good may remain in animal food.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:50
verses.text: So much on the subject of time.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:51
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:52
verses.text: As for motion, and tossing, and rubbing, if these give the divine nature the opportunity of escaping from these substances, many things of the same kind are against you, which are improved by motion.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:53
verses.text: In some grains the juice resembles wine, and is excellent when moved about.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:54
verses.text: Indeed, as must not be overlooked, this kind of drink produces intoxication rapidly; and yet you never called the juice of grain the poison of the princes of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:55
verses.text: There is a preparation of water, thickened with a little meal, which is the better of being shaken, and, strange to say, is lighter in color when the light is gone.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:56
verses.text: The pastry cook stirs honey for a long time to give it this light color, and to make its sweetness milder and less unwholesome: you must explain how this can come from the loss of good.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:57
verses.text: Again, if you prefer to test the presence of God by the agreeable effects on the hearing, and not sight, or smell, or taste, harps get their strings and pipes their bones from animals; and these become musical by being dried, and rubbed, and twisted.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:58
verses.text: So the pleasures of music, which you hold to have come from the divine kingdom, are obtained from the refuse of dead animals, and that, too, when they are dried by time, and lessened by rubbing, and stretched by twisting.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:59
verses.text: Such rough treatment, according to you, drives the divine substance from living objects; even cooking them, you say, does this.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:60
verses.text: Why then are boiled thistles not unwholesome? Is it because God, or part of God, leaves them when they are cooked?  47.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:61
verses.text: Why mention all the particulars, when it is difficult to enumerate them? Nor is it necessary; for every one knows how many things are sweeter and more wholesome when cooked.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:62
verses.text: This ought not to be, if, as you suppose, things lose the good by being thus moved about.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:63
verses.text: I do not suppose that you will find any proof from your bodily senses that flesh is unclean, and defiles the souls of those who eat it, because fruits, when plucked and shaken about in various ways, become flesh; especially as you hold that vinegar, in its age and fermentation, is cleaner than wine, and the mead you drink is nothing else than cooked wine, which ought to be more impure than wine, if material things lose the divine members by being moved about and cooked.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:64
verses.text: But if not, you have no reason to think that fruits, when plucked, kept, handled, cooked, and digested, are forsaken by the good, and therefore supply most unclean matter for the formation of bodies.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:65
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:66
verses.text: But if it is not from their color and appearance, and smell and taste, that you think the good to be in these things, what else can you bring forward? Do you prove it from the strength and vigor which those things seem to lose when they are separated from the earth and put to use? If this is your reason (though its erroneousness is seen at once, from the fact that the strength of some things is increased after their separation from the earth, as in the case already mentioned of wine, which becomes stronger from age),—if the strength, then, is your reason, it would follow that the part of God is to be found in no food more abundantly than in flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:67
verses.text: For athletes, who especially require vigor and energy, are not in the habit of feeding on cabbage and fruit without animal food.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:68
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:69
verses.text: Is your reason for thinking the bodies of trees better than our bodies, that flesh is nourished by trees and not trees by flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:70
verses.text: You forget the obvious fact that plants, when manured with dung, become richer and more fertile and crops heavier, though you think it your gravest charge against flesh that it is the abode of dung.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:71
verses.text: This then gives nourishment to things you consider clean, though it is, according to you, the most unclean part of what you consider unclean.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:72
verses.text: But if you dislike flesh because it springs from sexual intercourse, you should be pleased with the flesh of worms, which are bred in such numbers, and of such a size, in fruits, in wood, and in the earth itself, without any sexual intercourse.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:73
verses.text: But there is some insincerity in this.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:74
verses.text: For if you were displeased with flesh because it is formed from the cohabitation of father and mother, you would not say that those princes of darkness were born from the fruits of their own trees; for no doubt you think worse of these princes than of flesh, which you refuse to eat.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:75
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:76
verses.text: Your idea that all the souls of animals come from the food of their parents, from which confinement you pretend to liberate the divine substance which is held bound in your viands, is quite inconsistent with your abstinence from flesh, and makes it a pressing duty for you to eat animal food.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:77
verses.text: For if souls are bound in the body by those who eat animal food, why do you not secure their liberation by being beforehand in eating the food? You reply, it is not from the animal food that the good part comes which those people bring into bondage, but from the vegetables which they take with their meat.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:78
verses.text: What will you say then of the souls of lions, who feed only on flesh? They drink, is the reply, and so the soul is drawn in from the water and confined in flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:79
verses.text: But what of birds without number? What of eagles, which eat only flesh, and need no drink? Here you are at a loss, and can find no answer.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:80
verses.text: For if the soul comes from food, and there are animals which neither drink anything nor have any food but flesh, and yet bring forth young, there must be some soul in flesh; and you are bound to try your plan of purifying it by eating the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:81
verses.text: Or will you say that a pig has a soul of light, because it eats vegetables, and drinks water; and that the eagle, because it eats only flesh, has a soul of darkness, though it is so fond of the sun?  51.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:82
verses.text: What a confusion of ideas! What amazing fatuity! All this you would have escaped, if you had rejected idle fictions, and had followed what truth sanctions in abstinence from food, which would have taught you that sumptuous eating is to be avoided, not to escape pollution, as there is nothing of the kind, but to subdue the sensual appetite.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:83
verses.text: For should any one, from inattention to the nature of things, and the properties of the soul and body, allow that the soul is polluted by animal food, you will admit that it is much much more defiled by sensuality.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:84
verses.text: Is it reasonable, then, or rather, is it not most unreasonable, to expel from the number of the elect a man who, perhaps for his health's sake, takes some animal food without sensual appetite; while, if a man eagerly devours peppered truffles, you can only reprove him for excess, but cannot condemn him as abusing your symbol? So one who has been induced, not by sensuality, but for health, to eat part of a fowl, cannot remain among your elect; though one may remain who has yielded voluntarily to an excessive appetite for comfits and cakes without animal matter.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:85
verses.text: You retain the man plunged in the defilements of sensuality, and dismiss the man polluted, as you think, by the mere food; though you allow that the defilement of sensuality is far greater than that of meat.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:86
verses.text: You keep hold of one who gloats with delight over highly-seasoned vegetables, unable to keep possession of himself; while you shut out one who, to satisfy hunger, takes whatever comes, if suitable for nourishment, ready either to use the food, or to let it go.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:87
verses.text: Admirable customs! Excellent morals! Notable temperance!  52.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:88
verses.text: Again, the notion that it is unlawful for any one but the elect to touch as food what is brought to your meals for what you call purification, leads to shameful and sometimes to criminal practices.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:89
verses.text: For sometimes so much is brought that it cannot easily be eaten up by a few; and as it is considered sacrilege to give what is left to others, or, at least, to throw it away, you are obliged to eat to excess, from the desire to purify, as you call it, all that is given.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:90
verses.text: Then, when you are full almost to bursting, you cruelly use force in making the boys of your sect eat the rest.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:91
verses.text: So it was charged against some one at Rome that he killed some poor children, by compelling them to eat for this superstitious reason.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:92
verses.text: This I should not believe, did I not know how sinful you consider it to give this food to those who are not elect, or, at any rate, to throw it away.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:93
verses.text: So the only way is to eat it; and this leads every day to gluttony, and may sometimes lead to murder.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:94
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:95
verses.text: For the same reason you forbid giving bread to beggars.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:96
verses.text: By way of showing compassion, or rather of avoiding reproach, you advise to give money.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:97
verses.text: The cruelty of this is equalled by its stupidity.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:98
verses.text: For suppose a place where food cannot be purchased: the beggar will die of starvation, while you, in your wisdom and benevolence, have more mercy on a cucumber than on a human being! This is in truth (for how could it be better designated) pretended compassion, and real cruelty.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:99
verses.text: Then observe the stupidity.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:100
verses.text: What if the beggar buys bread for himself with the money you give him? Will the divine part, as you call it, not suffer the same in him when he buys the food as it would have suffered if he had taken it as a gift from you? So this sinful beggar plunges in corruption part of God eager to escape, and is aided in this crime by your money! But you in your great sagacity think it enough that you do not give to one about to commit murder a man to kill, though you knowingly give him money to procure somebody to be killed.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:101
verses.text: Can any madness go beyond this? The result is, that either the man dies if he cannot get food for his money, or the food itself dies if he gets it.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:102
verses.text: The one is true murder; the other what you call murder: though in both cases you incur the guilt of real murder.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:103
verses.text: Again, there is the greatest folly and absurdity in allowing your followers to eat animal food, while you forbid them to kill animals.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:104
verses.text: If this food does not defile, take it yourselves.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 17:105
verses.text: If it defiles, what can be more unreasonable than to think it more sinful to separate the soul of a pig from its body than to defile the soul of a man with the pig's flesh.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 17.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:2
verses.text: —Description of the Symbol of the Hands Among the Manich aeans.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:3
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:4
verses.text: We must now notice and discuss the symbol of the hands.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:5
verses.text: And, in the first place, your abstaining from the slaughter of animals and from injuring plants is shown by Christ to be mere superstition; for, on the ground that there is no community of rights between us and brutes and trees, He both sent the devils into an herd of swine,  and withered by His curse a tree in which He had found no fruit.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:6
verses.text: The swine assuredly had not sinned, nor had the tree.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:7
verses.text: We are not so insane as to think that a tree is fruitful or barren by its own choice.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:8
verses.text: Nor is it any reply to say that our Lord wished in these actions to teach some other truths; for every one knows that.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:9
verses.text: But assuredly the Son of God would not commit murder to illustrate truth, if you call the destruction of a tree or of an animal murder.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:10
verses.text: The signs which Christ wrought in the case of men, with whom we certainly have a community of rights, were in healing, not in killing them.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:11
verses.text: And it would have been the same in the case of beasts and trees, if we had that community with them which you imagine.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:12
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:13
verses.text: I think it right to refer here to the authority of Scripture, because we cannot here enter on a profound discussion about the soul of animals, or the kind of life in trees.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:14
verses.text: But as you preserve the right to call the Scriptures corrupted, in case you should find them too strongly opposed to you,—although you have never affirmed the passages about the tree and the herd of swine to be spurious,—still, lest some day you should wish to say this of them too, when you find how much they are against you, I will adhere to my plan, and will ask you, who are so liberal in your promises of evidence and truth, to tell me first what harm is done to a tree, I say not by plucking a leaf or an apple,—for which, however, one of you would be condemned at once as having abused the symbol, if he did it intentionally, and not accidentally,—but if you tear it up by the root.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:15
verses.text: For the soul in trees, which, according to you, is a rational soul, is, in your theory, freed from bondage when the tree is cut down,—a bondage, too, where it suffered great misery and got no profit.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:16
verses.text: For it is well known that you, in the words of your founder, threaten as a great, though not the greatest punishment, the change from a man to a tree; and it is not probable that the soul in a tree can grow in wisdom as it does in a man.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:17
verses.text: There is the best reason for not killing a man, in case you should kill one whose wisdom or virtue might be of use to many, or one who might have attained to wisdom, whether by the advice of another without himself, or by divine illumination in his own mind.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:18
verses.text: And the more wisdom the soul has when it leaves the body, the more profitable is its departure, as we know both from well-grounded reasoning and from wide-spread belief.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:19
verses.text: Thus to cut down a tree is to set free the soul from a body in which it makes no progress in wisdom.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:20
verses.text: You—the holy men, I mean—ought to be mainly occupied in cutting down trees, and in leading the souls thus emancipated to better things by prayers and psalms.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:21
verses.text: Or can this be done only with the souls which you take into your belly, instead of aiding them by your understanding?  56.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:22
verses.text: And you cannot escape the admission that the souls in trees make no progress in wisdom while they are there, when you are asked why no apostle was sent to teach trees as well as men, or why the apostle sent to men did not preach the truth to trees also.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:23
verses.text: Your reply must be, that the souls while in such bodies cannot understand the divine precepts.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:24
verses.text: But this reply lands you in great difficulties; for you declare that these souls can hear your voices and understand what you say, and see bodies and their motions, and even discern thoughts.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:25
verses.text: If this is true, why could they learn nothing from the apostle of light? Why could they not learn even much better than we, since they can see into the mind? Your master, who, as you say, has difficulty in teaching you by speech, might have taught these souls by thought; for they could see his ideas in his mind before he expressed them.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:26
verses.text: But if this is untrue, consider into what errors you have fallen.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:27
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:28
verses.text: As for your not plucking fruits or pulling up vegetables yourselves, while you get your followers to pluck and pull and bring them to you, that you may confer benefits not only on those who bring the food but on the food which is brought, what thoughtful person can bear to hear this? For, first, it matters not whether you commit a crime yourself, or wish another to commit it for you.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:29
verses.text: You deny that you wish this! How then can relief be given to the divine part contained in lettuce and leeks, unless some one pull them and bring them to the saints to be purified.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:30
verses.text: And again, if you were passing through a field where the right of friendship permitted you to pluck anything you wished, what would you do if you saw a crow on the point of eating a fig? Does not, according to your ideas, the fig itself seem to address you and to beg of you piteously to pluck it yourself and give it burial in a holy belly, where it may be purified and restored, rather than that the crow should swallow it and make it part of his cursed body, and then hand it over to bondage and torture in other forms? If this is true, how cruel you are! If not, how silly! What can be more contrary to your opinions than to break the symbol? What can be more unkind to the member of God than to keep it?  58.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:31
verses.text: This supposes the truth of your false and vain ideas.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:32
verses.text: But you can be shown guilty of plain and positive cruelty flowing from the same error.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:33
verses.text: For were any one lying on the road, his body wasted with disease, weary with journeying, and half-dead from his sufferings, and able only to utter some broken words, and if eating a pear would do him good as an astringent, and were he to beg you to help him as you passed by, and were he to implore you to bring the fruit from a neighboring tree, with no divine or human prohibition to prevent your doing so, while the man is sure to die for the want of it, you, a Christian man and a saint, will rather pass on and abandon a man thus suffering and entreating, lest the tree should lament the loss of its fruit, and you should be doomed to the punishment threatened by Manich aeus for breaking the symbol.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:34
verses.text: Strange customs, and strange harmlessness!  59.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:35
verses.text: Now, as regards killing animals, and the reasons for your opinion, much that has been said will apply also to this.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:36
verses.text: For what harm will be done to the soul of a wolf by killing the wolf, since the wolf, as long as it lives, will be a wolf, and will not listen to any preacher, or give up, in the least, shedding the blood of sheep; and, by killing it, the rational soul, as you think, will be set free from its confinement in the body? But you make this slaughter unlawful even for your followers; for you think it worse than that of trees.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:37
verses.text: And in this there is not much fault to be found with your senses,—that is, your bodily senses.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:38
verses.text: For we see and hear by their cries that animals die with pain, although man disregards this in a beast, with which, as not having a rational soul, we have no community of rights.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:39
verses.text: But as to your senses in the observation of trees, you must be entirely blind.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:40
verses.text: For not to mention that there are no movements in the wood expressive of pain, what is clearer than that a tree is never better than when it is green and flourishing, gay with flowers, and rich in fruit? And this comes generally and chiefly from pruning.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:41
verses.text: But if it felt the iron, as you suppose, it ought to die of wounds so many, so severe, instead of sprouting at the places, and reviving with such manifest delight.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:42
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:43
verses.text: But why do you think it a greater crime to destroy animals than plants, although you hold that plants have a purer soul than animals? There is a compensation, we are told, when part of what is taken from the fields is given to the elect and the saints to be purified.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:44
verses.text: This has already been refuted; and it has, I think, been proved sufficiently that there is no reason for saying that more of the good part is found in vegetables than in flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:45
verses.text: But should any one support himself by selling butcher-meat, and spend the whole profit of his business in purchasing food for your elect, and bring larger supplies for those saints than any peasant or farmer, will he not plead this compensation as a warrant for his killing animals? But there is, we are told, some other mysterious reason; for a cunning man can always find some resource in the secrets of nature when addressing unlearned people.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:46
verses.text: The story, then, is that the heavenly princes who were taken from the race of darkness and bound, and have a place assigned them in this region by the Creator of the world, have animals on the earth specially belonging to them, each having those coming from his own stock and class; and they hold the slaughterers of those animals guilty, and do not allow them to leave the earth, but harass them as much as they can with pains and torments.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:47
verses.text: What simple man will not be frightened by this, and, seeing nothing in the darkness shrouding these things, will not think that the fact is as described? But I will hold to my purpose, with God's help, to rebut mysterious falsehood by the plainest truth.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:48
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:49
verses.text: Tell me, then, if animals on land and in water come in regular succession by ordinary generation from this race of princes, since the origin of animal life is traced to the abortive births in that race;—tell me, I say, whether bees and frogs, and many other creatures not sprung from sexual intercourse,  may be killed with impunity.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:50
verses.text: We are told they cannot.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:51
verses.text: So it is not on account of their relation to certain princes that you forbid your followers to kill animals.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:52
verses.text: Or if you make a general relationship to all bodies, the princes would be equally concerned about trees, which you do not require your followers to spare.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:53
verses.text: You are brought back to the weak reply, that the injuries done in the case of plants are atoned for by the fruits which your followers bring to your church.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:54
verses.text: For this implies that those who slaughter animals, and sell their flesh in the market, if they are your followers, and if they bring to you vegetables bought with their gains, may think nothing of the daily slaughter, and are cleared of any sin that may be in it by your repasts.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:55
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:56
verses.text: But if you say that, in order to expiate the slaughter, the thing must be given as food, as in the case of fruits and vegetables,—which cannot be done, because the elect do not eat flesh, and so your followers must not slaughter animals,—what reply will you give in the case of thorns and weeds, which farmers destroy in clearing their fields, while they cannot bring any food to you from them? How can there be pardon for such destruction, which gives no nourishment to the saints? Perhaps you also put away any sin committed, for the benefit of the fruits and vegetables, by eating some of these.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:57
verses.text: What then if the fields are plundered by locusts, mice, or rats, as we see often happen? Can your rustic follower kill these with impunity, because he sins for the good of his crops? Here you are at a loss; for you either allow your followers to kill animals, which your founder prohibited, or you forbid them to be cultivators, which he made lawful.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:58
verses.text: Indeed, you sometimes go so far as to say that an usurer is more harmless than a cultivator,—you feel so much more for melons than for men.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:59
verses.text: Rather than hurt the melons, you would have a man ruined as a debtor.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:60
verses.text: Is this desirable and praiseworthy justice, or not rather atrocious and damnable error? Is this commendable compassion, or not rather detestable barbarity?  63.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:61
verses.text: What, again, of your not abstaining yourselves from the slaughter of lice, bugs, and fleas? You think it a sufficient excuse for this to say that these are the dirt of our bodies.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:62
verses.text: But this is clearly untrue of fleas and bugs; for every one knows that these animals do not come from our bodies.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:63
verses.text: Besides, if you abhor sexual intercourse as much as you pretend to do, you should think those animals all the cleaner which come from our bodies without any other generation; for although they produce offspring of their own, they are not produced in ordinary generation from us.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:64
verses.text: Again, if we must consider as most filthy the production of living bodies, still worse must be the production of dead bodies.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:65
verses.text: There must be less harm, therefore, in killing a rat, a snake, or a scorpion, which you constantly say come from our dead bodies.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:66
verses.text: But to pass over what is less plain and certain, it is a common opinion regarding bees that they come from the carcases of oxen; so there is no harm in killing them.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:67
verses.text: Or if this too is doubted, every one allows that beetles, at least, are bred in the ball of mud which they make and bury.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:68
verses.text: You ought therefore to consider these animals, and others that it would be tedious to specify, more unclean than your lice; and yet you think it sinful to kill them, though it would be foolish not to kill the lice.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:69
verses.text: Perhaps you hold the lice cheap because they are small.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:70
verses.text: But if an animal is to be valued by its size, you must prefer a camel to a man.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:71
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:72
verses.text: Here we may use the gradation which often perplexed us when we were your followers.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:73
verses.text: For if a flea may be killed on account of its small size, so may the fly which is bred in beans.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:74
verses.text: And if this, so also may one of a little larger size, for its size at birth is even less.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:75
verses.text: Then again, a bee may be killed, for its young is no larger than a fly.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:76
verses.text: So on to the young of a locust, and to a locust; and then to the young of a mouse, and to a mouse.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:77
verses.text: And, to cut short, it is clear we may come at last to an elephant; so that one who thinks it no sin to kill a flea, because of its small size, must allow that it would be no sin in him to kill this huge creature.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 18:78
verses.text: But I think enough has been said of these absurdities.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:1
verses.text: Chapter 18.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:2
verses.text: —Of the Symbol of the Breast, and of the Shameful Mysteries of the Manich aeans.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:3
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:4
verses.text: Lastly, there is the symbol of the breast, in which your very questionable chastity consists.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:5
verses.text: For though you do not forbid sexual intercourse, you, as the apostle long ago said, forbid marriage in the proper sense, although this is the only good excuse for such intercourse.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:6
verses.text: No doubt you will exclaim against this, and will make it a reproach against us that you highly esteem and approve perfect chastity, but do not forbid marriage, because your followers—that is, those in the second grade among you—are allowed to have wives.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:7
verses.text: After you have said this with great noise and heat, I will quietly ask, Is it not you who hold that begetting children, by which souls are confined in flesh, is a greater sin than cohabitation? Is it not you who used to counsel us to observe as much as possible the time when a woman, after her purification, is most likely to conceive, and to abstain from cohabitation at that time, lest the soul should be entangled in flesh? This proves that you approve of having a wife, not for the procreation of children, but for the gratification of passion.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:8
verses.text: In marriage, as the marriage law declares, the man and woman come together for the procreation of children.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:9
verses.text: Therefore whoever makes the procreation of children a greater sin than copulation, forbids marriage, and makes the woman not a wife, but a mistress, who for some gifts presented to her is joined to the man to gratify his passion.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:10
verses.text: Where there is a wife there must be marriage.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:11
verses.text: But there is no marriage where motherhood is not in view; therefore neither is there a wife.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:12
verses.text: In this way you forbid marriage.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:13
verses.text: Nor can you defend yourselves successfully from this charge, long ago brought against you prophetically by the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:14
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:15
verses.text: Moreover, when you are so eager in your desire to prevent the soul from being confined in flesh by conjugal intercourse, and so eager in asserting that the soul is set free from seed by the food of the saints, do you not sanction, unhappy beings, the suspicion entertained about you? For why should it be true regarding corn and beans and lentils and other seeds, that when you eat them you wish to set free the soul, and not true of the seeds of animals? For what you say of the flesh of a dead animal, that it is unclean because there is no soul in it, cannot be said of the seed of the animal; for you hold that it keeps confined the soul which will appear in the offspring, and you avow that the soul of Manich aeus himself is thus confined.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:16
verses.text: And as your followers cannot bring these seeds to you for purification, who will not suspect that you make this purification secretly among yourselves, and hide it from your followers, in case they should leave you?  If you do not these things, as it is to be hoped you do not, still you see how open to suspicion your superstition is, and how impossible it is to blame men for thinking what your own profession suggests, when you maintain that you set free souls from bodies and from senses by eating and drinking.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:17
verses.text: I wish to say no more about this: you see yourselves what room there is here for denunciation.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 19:18
verses.text: But as the matter is one rather to repress than to invite remark, and also as throughout my discourse my purpose appears of exaggerating nothing, and of keeping to bare facts and arguments, we shall pass on to other matters.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:1
verses.text: Chapter 19.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:2
verses.text: —Crimes of the Manich aeans.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:3
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:4
verses.text: We see then, now, the nature of your three symbols.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:5
verses.text: These are your customs.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:6
verses.text: This is the end of your notable precepts, in which there is nothing sure, nothing steadfast, nothing consistent, nothing irreproachable, but all doubtful, or rather undoubtedly and entirely false, all contradictory, abominable, absurd.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:7
verses.text: In a word, evil practices are detected in your customs so many and so serious, that one wishing to denounce them all, if he were at all able to enlarge, would require at least a separate treatise for each.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:8
verses.text: Were you to observe these, and to act up to your profession, no childishness, or folly, or absurdity would go beyond yours; and when you praise and teach these things without doing them, you display craft and deceit and malevolence equal to anything that can be described or imagined.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:9
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:10
verses.text: During nine full years that I attended you with great earnestness and assiduity, I could not hear of one of your elect who was not found transgressing these precepts, or at least was not suspected of doing so.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:11
verses.text: Many were caught at wine and animal food, many at the baths; but this we only heard by report.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:12
verses.text: Some were proved to have seduced other men's wives, so that in this case I could not doubt the truth of the charge.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:13
verses.text: But suppose this, too, a report rather than a fact.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:14
verses.text: I myself saw, and not I only, but others who have either escaped from that superstition, or will, I hope, yet escape,—we saw, I say, in a square in Carthage, on a road much frequented, not one, but more than three of the elect walking behind us, and accosting some women with such indecent sounds and gestures as to outdo the boldness and insolence of all ordinary rascals.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:15
verses.text: And it was clear that this was quite habitual, and that they behaved in this way to one another, for no one was deterred by the presence of a companion, showing that most of them, if not all, were affected with this evil tendency.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:16
verses.text: For they did not all come from one house, but lived in quite different places, and quite accidentally left together the place where they had met.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:17
verses.text: It was a great shock to us, and we lodged a complaint about it.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:18
verses.text: But who thought of inflicting punishment,—I say not by separation from the church, but even by severe rebuke in proportion to the heinousness of the offence?  69.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:19
verses.text: All the excuse given for the impunity of those men was that, at that time, when their meetings were forbidden by law, it was feared that the persons suffering punishment might retaliate by giving information.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:20
verses.text: What then of their assertion that they will always have persecution in this world, for which they suppose that they will be thought the more of? for this is the application they make of the words about the world hating them.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:21
verses.text: And they will have it that truth must be sought for among them, because, in the promise of the Holy Spirit, the Paraclete, it is said that the world cannot receive Him.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:22
verses.text: This is not the place to discuss this question.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:23
verses.text: But clearly, if you are always to be persecuted, even to the end of the world, there will be no end to this laxity, and to the unchecked spread of all this immorality, from your fear of giving offence to men of this character.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:24
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:25
verses.text: This answer was also given to us, when we reported to the very highest authorities that a woman had complained to us that in a meeting, where she was along with other women, not doubting of the sanctity of these people, some of the elect came in, and when one of them had put out the lamp, one, whom she could not distinguish, tried to embrace her, and would have forced her into sin, had she not escaped by crying out.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:26
verses.text: How common must we conclude the practice to have been which led to the misdeed on this occasion! And this was done on the night when you keep the feast of vigils.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:27
verses.text: Forsooth, besides the fear of information being given, no one could bring the offender before the bishop, as he had so well guarded against being recognized.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:28
verses.text: As if all who entered along with him were not implicated in the crime; for in their indecent merriment they all wished the lamp to be put out.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:29
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:30
verses.text: Then what wide doors were opened for suspicions, when we saw them full of envy, full of covetousness, full of greed for costly foods, constantly at strife, easily excited about trifles! We concluded that they were not competent to abstain from the things they professed to abstain from, if they found an opportunity in secret or in the dark.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:31
verses.text: There were two of sufficiently good character, of active minds, and leaders in their debates, with whom we had a more particular and intimate acquaintance than with the rest.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:32
verses.text: One of them was much associated with us, because he was also engaged in liberal studies; he is said to be now an elder there.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:33
verses.text: These two were very jealous of one another, and one accused the other—not openly, but in conversation, as he had opportunity, and in whispers—of having made a criminal assault on the wife of one of the followers.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:34
verses.text: He again, in clearing himself to us, brought the same charge against another of the elect, who lived with this follower as his most trusted friend.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:35
verses.text: He had, going in suddenly, caught this man with the woman, and his enemy and rival had advised the woman and her paramour to raise this false report about him, that he might not be believed if he gave any information.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:36
verses.text: We were much distressed, and took it greatly to heart, that although there was a doubt about the assault on the woman, the jealous feeling in those two men, than whom we found none better in the place, showed itself so keenly, and inevitably raised a suspicion of other things.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:37
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:38
verses.text: Another thing was, that we very often saw in theatres men belonging to the elect, men of years and, it was supposed, of character, along with a hoary-headed elder.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:39
verses.text: We pass over the youths, whom we used to come upon quarrelling about the people connected with the stage and the races; from which we may safely conclude how they would be able to refrain in secret, when they could not subdue the passion by which they were exposed in the eyes of their followers, bringing on them disgrace and flight.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:40
verses.text: In the case of the saint, whose discussions we attended in the street of the fig-sellers, would his atrocious crime have been discovered if he had been able to make the dedicated virgin his wife without making her pregnant? The swelling womb betrayed the secret and unthought-of iniquity.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:41
verses.text: When her brother, a young man, heard of it from his mother, he felt keenly the injury, but refrained, from regard to religion, from a public accusation.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:42
verses.text: He succeeded in getting the man expelled from that church, for such conduct cannot always be tolerated; and that the crime might not be wholly unpunished, he arranged with some of his friends to have the man well beaten and kicked.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:43
verses.text: When he was thus assailed, he cried out that they should spare him, from regard to the authority of the opinion of Manich aeus, that Adam the first hero had sinned, and was a greater saint after his sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:44
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:45
verses.text: This, in fact, is your notion about Adam and Eve.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:46
verses.text: It is a long story; but I will touch only on what concerns the present matter.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:47
verses.text: You say that Adam was produced from his parents, the abortive princes of darkness; that he had in his soul the most part of light, and very little of the opposite race.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:48
verses.text: So while he lived a holy life, on account of the prevalence of good, still the opposite part in him was stirred up, so that he was led away into conjugal intercourse.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:49
verses.text: Thus he fell and sinned, but afterwards lived in greater holiness.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:50
verses.text: Now, my complaint is not so much about this wicked man, who, under the garb of an elect and holy man, brought such shame and reproach on a family of strangers by his shocking immorality.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:51
verses.text: I do not charge you with this.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:52
verses.text: Let it be attributed to the abandoned character of the man, and not to your habits.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:53
verses.text: I blame the man for the atrocity, and not you.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:54
verses.text: Still there is this in you all that cannot, as far as I can see, be admitted or tolerated, that while you hold the soul to be part of God, you still maintain that the mixture of a little evil prevailed over the superior force and quantity of good.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 20:55
verses.text: Who that believes this, when incited by passion, will not find here an excuse, instead of checking and controlling his passion?.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:1
verses.text: Chapter 20.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:2
verses.text: —Disgraceful Conduct Discovered at Rome.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:3
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:4
verses.text: What more shall I say of your customs? I have mentioned what I found myself when I was in the city when the things were done.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:5
verses.text: To go through all that happened at Rome in my absence would take a long time.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:6
verses.text: I will, however, give a short account of it; for the matter became so notorious, that even the absent could not remain in ignorance of it.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:7
verses.text: And when I was afterwards in Rome, I ascertained the truth of all I had heard, although the story was told me by an eye-witness whom I knew so well and esteemed so highly, that I could not feel any doubt about it.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:8
verses.text: One of your followers, then, quite equal to the elect in their far-famed abstinence, for he was both liberally educated, and was in the habit of defending your sect with great zeal, took it very ill that he had cast in his teeth the vile conduct of the elect, who lived in all kinds of places, and went hither and thither for lodging of the worst description.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:9
verses.text: He therefore desired, if possible, to assemble all who were willing to live according to the precepts into his own house, and to maintain them at his own expense; for he was above the average in carelessness as to spending money, besides being above the average in the amount he had to spend.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:10
verses.text: He complained that his efforts were hindered by the remissness of the bishops, whose assistance he required for success.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:11
verses.text: At last one of your bishops was found,—a man, as I know, very rude and unpolished, but somehow, from his very moroseness, the more inclined to strict observance of morality.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:12
verses.text: The follower eagerly lays hold of this man as the person he had long wished for and found at last, and relates his whole plan.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:13
verses.text: He approves and assents, and agrees to be the first to take up his abode in the house.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:14
verses.text: When this was done, all the elect who could be at Rome were assembled there.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:15
verses.text: The rule of life in the epistle of Manich aeus was laid before them.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:16
verses.text: Many thought it intolerable, and left; not a few felt ashamed, and stayed.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:17
verses.text: They began to live as they had agreed, and as this high authority enjoined.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:18
verses.text: The follower all the time was zealously enforcing everything on everybody, though never, in any case, what he did not undertake himself.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:19
verses.text: Meanwhile quarrels constantly arose among the elect.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:20
verses.text: They charged one another with crimes, all which he lamented to hear, and managed to make them unintentionally expose one another in their altercations.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:21
verses.text: The revelations were vile beyond description.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:22
verses.text: Thus appeared the true character of those who were unlike the rest in being willing to bend to the yoke of the precepts.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:23
verses.text: What then is to be suspected, or rather, concluded, of the others? To come to a close, they gathered together on one occasion and complained that they could not keep the regulations.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:24
verses.text: Then came rebellion.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:25
verses.text: The follower stated his case most concisely, that either all must be kept, or the man who had given such a sanction to such precepts, which no one could fulfill, must be thought a great fool.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:26
verses.text: But, as was inevitable, the wild clamor of the mob prevailed over the opinion of one man.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:27
verses.text: The bishop himself gave way at last, and took to flight with great disgrace; and he was said to have got in provisions by stealth, contrary to rule, which were often discovered.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:28
verses.text: He had a supply of money from his private purse, which he carefully kept concealed.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:29
Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:30
verses.text: If you say these things are false, you contradict what is too clear and public.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:31
verses.text: But you may say so if you like.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:32
verses.text: For, as the things are certain, and easily known by those who wish to know them, those who deny that they are true show what their habit of telling the truth is.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:33
verses.text: But you have other replies with which I do not find fault.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:34
verses.text: For you either say that some do keep your precepts, and that they should not be mixed up with the guilty in condemning the others; or that the whole inquiry into the character of the members of your sect is wrong, for the question is of the character of the profession.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Morals of the Manichaeans 21:35
verses.text: Should I grant both of these (although you can neither point out those faithful observers of the precepts, nor clear your heresy of all those frivolities and iniquities), still I must insist on knowing why you heap reproaches on Christians of the Catholic name on seeing the immoral life of some, while you either have the effrontery to repel inquiry about your members, or the still greater effrontery not to repel it, wishing it to be understood that in your scanty membership there are some unknown individuals who keep the precepts they profess, but that among the multitudes in the Catholic Church there are none.
